content.json:
# [DOD CIO Zero Trust](https://dodcio.defense.gov/Portals/0/Documents/Library/DoD-ZTExecutionRoadmap.pdf) - NEED TO WORK ON THIS LAYOUT
---

Our adversaries are in our networks, exfiltrating our data, and exploiting the Department‚Äôs users.
The rapid growth of these offensive threats emphasizes the need for the Department of Defense 
(DoD) to adapt and significantly improve our deterrence strategies and cybersecurity 
implementations. Defending DoD networks with high-powered and ever-more sophisticated 
perimeter defenses is no longer sufficient for achieving cyber resiliency and securing our information enterprise that spans geographic borders, interfaces with external partners, and support to millions of authorized users, many of which now require access to DoD networks outside traditional boundaries, such as work from home. To meet these challenges, the DoD requires an enhanced cybersecurity framework built upon Zero Trust principles that must be adopted across the Department, enterprise-wide, as quickly as possible as described within this document. 
This urgency means that our colleagues, our warfighters, and every member of DoD must adopt 
a Zero Trust mindset, regardless of whether they work in technology or cybersecurity or the 
Human Resource department. This ‚Äúnever trust, always verify‚Äù mindset requires us to take 
responsibility for the security of our devices, applications, assets, and services; users are granted access to only the data they need and when needed. We all must play a role in combating our 
adversaries by acting quickly and correctly to address security threats wherever and whenever 
they arise. 
Zero Trust is much more than an IT solution. Zero Trust may include certain products but is not 
a capability or device that may be bought. The journey to Zero Trust requires all DoD 
Components to adopt and integrate Zero Trust capabilities, technologies, solutions, and 
processes across their architectures, systems, and within their budget and execution plans. 
Perhaps most importantly, they must also address Zero Trust requirements within their staffing, 
training, and professional development processes as well. " For more information, see theüí°[DoD CIO Zero Trust Strategy (Nov '22)](https://dodcio.defense.gov/Portals/0/Documents/Library/DoD-ZTStrategy.pdf)

links.linkLabel: Microsoft supports the DoD‚Äôs Zero Trust strategy

| where ResultType == 0

| sort by AppDisplayName asc

content.json:
### Graph 

Query Azure AD for all synchronized user objects using Microsoft Graph PowerShell: 
```
Connect-MgGraph -Scopes user.read.all 
Select-MgProfile beta 
Get-MgUser -Filter "OnPremisesSyncEnabled eq true" -All  
```
Verify no synchronized users are assigned Global Administrator role: 
```
Connect-MgGraph -Scopes RoleManagement.Read.All 
$roleid = $(Get-MgRoleManagementDirectoryRoleDefinition ` |?{$_.DisplayName -eq "Global Administrator"}).id 
$members = Get-MgRoleManagementDirectoryRoleAssignment ` 
| ?{$_.RoleDefinitionId -eq $roleid} 
foreach ($member in $members) { 
    $u = Get-MgUser -UserId $member.PrincipalId 
    if ($u.OnPremisesSyncEnabled -eq $true) { 
        "Synced user is member of Global Admins! $($u.UserPrincipalName)" | write-host -ForegroundColor Red 
        $flag = 1}} 
if (!($flag)) {Write-Host "Pass" -ForegroundColor Green}  
```
Find privileged users in Azure AD by checking assignments for Azure AD roles
```
$roles = <array of role names> 
Connect-MgGraph -Scopes RoleManagement.Read.All 
$privids = @() 
foreach ($role in $roles) { 
    $roleid = $(Get-MgRoleManagementDirectoryRoleDefinition ` 
| ?{$_.DisplayName -eq $roles}).id 
    $privids = $(Get-MgRoleManagementDirectoryRoleAssignment ` 
| ?{$_.RoleDefinitionId -eq $roleid}).PrincipalId 
} 
```

### PowerShell 
PowerShell Modules
```
Install-Module AzureAD
Get-AzureADAuditSignInLogs -Filter "startsWith(userPrincipalName,'JNiyomugabo@Contoso.com')"
Get-AzureADAuditSignInLogs -Filter "userDisplayName eq 'Jean Niyomugabo '"
Get-AzureADAuditSignInLogs -Filter "appId eq 'de8bc8b5-d9f9-48b1-a8ad-b748da725064'"
Get-AzureADAuditSignInLogs -Filter "appDisplayName eq 'myApp'"
```
Investigate role assignments to highly privileged Azure RBAC roles referencing the list in this section
```
Connect-AzAccount 
$roles = az role assignment list --subscription '6c29d1c6-f982-49d9-b9c3-a839236b8bf5' 
```

content.json:
## Implementation Methods

### 1.2.1 Implement App Based Permissions per Enterprise
1. Enterprise roles/attributes needed for user authorization to application functions and/or data have been registered with enterprise ICAM.
  1. Organizations using Azure AD Connect to synchronize on-premises Active Directory Domain Services with Azure AD should synchronize the recommended attributes needed for attribute-based access.
    1. View the on-premises synchronization status with Microsoft Graph PowerShell:

```
Connect-MgGraph$(Get-MgOrganization).AdditionalProperties.onPremisesSyncStatus.state 
```

  2. Dynamic Security Groups can target application assignment, Azure resource RBAC.
    1. Use MS Graph PowerShell to view all dynamic security groups:

```
 Connect-MgGraph-ScopesGroup.Read.AllGet-MgGroup|?{$\_.GroupTypes -eq"DynamicMembership"}
```

2. DoD Enterprise ICAM has self-service attribute/role registration service that enables application owners to add attributes or use existing enterprise attributes.
  1. Azure AD application owners can define and assign application roles.
  2. Custom Security Attributes provide the framework for Attribute-Based Access Control.
3. Privileged activities are fully migrated to PAM.
  1. Azure AD Privileged Identity Management is the PAM tool for M365 and Azure. Enable it using the Entra Portal following the [PIM Deployment Guide.](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/privileged-identity-management/pim-deployment-plan)
    1. Prepare to manage Azure AD roles and [assign roles with PIM](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/privileged-identity-management/pim-how-to-add-role-to-user).
    2. [Discover Azure resources to manage with PIM](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/privileged-identity-management/pim-resource-roles-discover-resources).
    3. [Bring groups into Privileged Identity Management (preview)](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/privileged-identity-management/groups-discover-groups)
 

 ### 1.2.2 Rule Based Dynamic Access Pt 1

1. Access to application's/service's functions and/or data are limited to users with appropriate enterprise attributes.
  1. Azure AD provides governance features for managing user assignments to applications.
    1. Dynamic security groups defined by user attributes can be used for assigning users to applications. 
    2. Azure AD Premium P2 customers can use [Entitlements Management](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/governance/entitlement-management-overview) for delegated access management and assignment to applications and resources within the organization.
  2. In addition to user assignments, Azure AD can control access for a given user based on sign-in context using Conditional Access Policies. This means fine-grained access control for an approved and assigned user can be enforced based on environmental details (device management state, authentication strength, risk, location, client app, etc.).
    1. Sign in to the **Entra Portal**  **√†**  **Azure Active Directory** √† **Applications** √† **Enterprise Applications**.
    2. Copy the Application ID for an enterprise application.
    3. Using this Application ID, find enabled Conditional Access Policies with MS Graph PowerShell:

```
Connect-MgGraph-ScopesPolicy.Read.All Select-MgProfilebeta$appid="02750a1b-9140-48e0-abee-e6b708e4765d"
Get-MgIdentityConditionalAccessPolicy | ?{($\_.state -eq'enabled') -and ($\_.Conditions.Applications.IncludeApplications -contains$appid-or ($\_.Conditions.Applications.IncludeApplications -eq'All'-and ($\_.Conditions.Applications.ExcludeApplications -notcontains$appid)))} 
```

2. All possible applications use JIT/JEA permissions for administrative users.
  1. Azure AD and Azure role permissions that support JIT/JEA can be discovered using PIM discovery and insights.
    1. Use PIM Discovery and insights to review role assignments and recommendations.
  2. Application assignments and Application Role assignments using Azure AD Security groups can integrate with Azure AD PIM by using PIM for Groups.
    1. Review application catalog for apps using privileged App Roles or AAD Group Membership.
    2. Use the Entra portal to [bring groups into Privileged Identity Management](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/privileged-identity-management/groups-discover-groups).
    3. Create Privileged Access Groups for any administrative App Roles using MS Graph PowerShell as needed:

```
New-MgGroup-DisplayName"MyPrivAccessGroup"-MailNickname"MyPrivAccessGroup"-SecurityEnabled-MailEnabled:$false-IsAssignableToRole 
```

[Assign eligibility for a group (preview)](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/privileged-identity-management/groups-assign-member-owner) using the Entra Portal.
    5. Replace the administrator Application Role assignment with the new Privileged Access Group.

| mv-expand todynamic(AuthenticationDetails)‚Äã
| extend ['Authentication Method'] = tostring(AuthenticationDetails.authenticationMethod)
| where ['Authentication Method'] !in ("Password","Previously satisfied")‚Äã
| summarize Count=count()by ['Authentication Method']‚Äã
| where isnotempty(['Authentication Method'])
| sort by Count desc
| render piechart
content.title: Multifactor Authentication In Use

content.query:
SigninLogs
| where ResultType == "500121"
| mv-expand todynamic(AuthenticationDetails)
| project AuthenticationDetails, ResultType, UserPrincipalName
| extend ['MFA Failure Type'] = tostring(parse_json(AuthenticationDetails).authenticationStepResultDetail)
| where ['MFA Failure Type'] startswith "MFA denied"
//| summarize Count=count()by ['MFA Failure Type'], UserPrincipalName //uncomment to see upn
| summarize Count=count()by ['MFA Failure Type']
content.title: MFA Failure Type

content.query:
//Visualize password vs passwordless signins per day

//Data connector required for this query - Azure Active Directory - Signin Logs

SigninLogs
| mv-expand todynamic(AuthenticationDetails)
| project TimeGenerated, AuthenticationDetails
| extend AuthMethod = tostring(AuthenticationDetails.authenticationMethod)
| summarize
    Passwordless=countif(AuthMethod in ("Windows Hello for Business", "Passwordless phone sign-in", "FIDO2 security key", "X.509 Certificate")),
    Password=countif(AuthMethod == "Password")
    by bin(TimeGenerated, 1d)
| render barchart with (title="Passwordless vs Password Authentication", ytitle="Count")
content.title: Password vs Passwordless Auth

content.query:
SigninLogs
| where ResultType == 0
| summarize
    ['Total Signin Count']=count(),
    ['Total MFA Count']=countif(AuthenticationRequirement == "multiFactorAuthentication"),
    ['Total non MFA Count']=countif(AuthenticationRequirement == "singleFactorAuthentication")
    by AppDisplayName
| project
    AppDisplayName,
    ['Total Signin Count'],
    ['Total MFA Count'],
    ['Total non MFA Count'],
   MFAPercentage=(todouble(['Total MFA Count']) * 100 / todouble(['Total Signin Count']))
| sort by ['Total Signin Count'] desc, MFAPercentage asc
content.title: Total MFA Count by App

content.query:
//Data connector required for this query - Azure Active Directory - Audit Logs

AuditLogs
| where OperationName in ("Add member to role in PIM completed (permanent)","Add member to role in PIM completed (timebound)")
//| where OperationName contains 'permanent'
| where TargetResources[2].type == "User"
| extend Actor = tostring(parse_json(tostring(InitiatedBy.user)).userPrincipalName)
| extend User = tostring(TargetResources[2].userPrincipalName)
| extend ['Azure AD Role Name'] = tostring(TargetResources[0].displayName)
| project TimeGenerated, Actor, User, ['Azure AD Role Name']
content.title: Permanently Assigned Role
content.noDataMessage: If query returns no results this means your PIM users are set to eligible, which is best security practices.

content.title: Privileged Users Actions

content.query:
//Detect when a group is added to Azure AD with the 'Azure AD roles can be assigned to this group' flag enabled

//Data connector required for this query - Azure Active Directory - Audit Logs

AuditLogs
//| where TimeGenerated > ago(90d)
| where OperationName == "Add group"
| where parse_json(tostring(TargetResources[0].modifiedProperties))[1].displayName == "IsAssignableToRole"
| where parse_json(tostring(parse_json(tostring(TargetResources[0].modifiedProperties))[1].newValue))[0] == true
| extend GroupName = tostring(parse_json(tostring(parse_json(tostring(TargetResources[0].modifiedProperties))[0].newValue))[0])
| extend Actor = tostring(parse_json(tostring(InitiatedBy.user)).userPrincipalName)
| extend ['Actor IP Address'] = tostring(parse_json(tostring(InitiatedBy.user)).ipAddress)
| project TimeGenerated, OperationName, GroupName, Actor, ['Actor IP Address']
content.title: New Role Assigned Group

## 2.1.1 - Device Health Tool Gap Analysis ### **Instructions:** ### ***Manual inventory of devices is created per organization w/ owners.***

i. View devices registered or joined to Azure AD:
- (1) To view Devices in the Azure Portal, navigate to **Azure Portal -> Search for and select ‚Äúdevices‚Äù -> Select ‚ÄúDevices‚Äù -> Select ‚ÄúAll Devices‚Äù** - (2) Find devices in Azure AD with [Microsoft Graph PowerShell](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.graph.identity.directorymanagement/get-mgdevice?view=graph-powershell-1.0): ``` powershell Connect-MgGraph -EnvironmentName USGovDoD Get-MgDevice ``` - (3) Use [Intune graph](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/api/resources/intune-graph-overview?view=graph-rest-1.0) to find devices registered to a particular user. ii. Use M365 Defender to view device inventory for computers and mobile, network, and IoT.

## 2.1.2 - NPE/PKI, Device Under Management ### **Instructions:** ***Non-person entities are managed via Org PKI and Org IDP***
i. Service Principals in Azure AD can use client certificates issued by the Org IDP. - (1) To view Service Principals in the Azure AD Portal, navigate to **Azure AD Portal -> Enterprise Applications** and change the Application type dropdown to "**All Applications**". - (2) **View Service Principals with MS Graph PowerShell: ``` powershell Get-MgServicePrincipal ``` - (3) **Find Service Principals using Password Credentials:** ``` powershell $apps = Get-MgApplication -All foreach ($app in $apps) { if ($app.KeyCredentials.KeyId) {write-host "$($app.Id) has a certificate credential" -ForegroundColor Green} elseif ($app.PasswordCredentials[0] -ne $null) {Write-host "$($app.Id) has password credential" -ForegroundColor Red} else {write-host "$($app.Id) has no credentials"} } ```

## 2.1.3 - Enterprise IDP Pt 1 ## ### **Instructions:** ***Non-person entities are managed via Org PKI and Org IDP*** i. View devices in Azure Active Directory. - (1) Find Registered Devices in Azure AD: ``` powershell Connect-MgGraph -Scopes Device.Read.All Get-MgDevice -Filter "TrustType eq `'Workplace`'" ``` - (2) Find Hybrid Azure AD Joined Devices in Azure AD: ``` powershell Get-MgDevice -Filter "TrustType eq `'ServerAd`'" ``` - (3) Find Azure AD Joined Devices in Azure AD: ``` powershell Get-MgDevice -Filter "TrustType eq `'AzureAd`'" ``` - (4) Find Managed Devices and their compliance state using the **Microsoft Entra Portal -> Azure Active Directory -> All Devices.**
ii. Use device-based conditions in Conditional Access Policies. - (1) Find CA Policies requiring Hybrid Azure AD Joined Device: ``` powershell Connect-MgGraph -Scopes Policy.Read.All Get-MgIdentityConditionalAccessPolicy | ?{($_.State -eq 'enabled') -and ($_.GrantControls.BuiltInControls -eq "domainJoinedDevice")} ``` - (2) Find CA Policies requiring Compliant Device: ``` powershell Get-MgIdentityConditionalAccessPolicy | ?{($_.State -eq 'enabled') -and ($_.GrantControls.BuiltInControls -eq "compliantDevice")} ```

## 2.1.4 - Enterprise IDP Pt 2 ### **Instructions:** ### ***Conditional device attributes are part of the IdP profile.***

i. Azure AD meets this ZT outcome directly since the sign in process captures environment attributes for the device including:
- (1) IP address (location) - (2) Device platform and client application - (3) Device state (registered, hybrid Azure AD Joined, compliant) ii. To Establish a conditional access policy - (a)¬†¬†¬†¬† To view conditional access policies in the Azure Portal, navigate to **Azure Portal -> Azure Active Directory -> Security -> Conditional Access** - (b) Instructions for running a script or PowerShell command: ``` powershell Get-AzureADMSConditionalAccessPolicy ```

parameters.label: Status
parameters.query:
SigninLogs

| summarize count()

SigninLogs
| where ResultType == 0
| summarize Count=count() by AppDisplayName
| render piechart

IdentityInfo | union BehaviorAnalytics
| where isnotempty(UserType)
| summarize count() by UserType
| render piechart
content.title: UEBA - IdentityInfo

## Control Requirements 4.1
| Descriptions        | Outcomes           | ZT Impact | 
|-|:-:|:-:|:-:|:-:|
| Data owners ensure that data is identified and inventoried and any changes to the data landscape are automatically detected and included within the catalog. The data landscape must then be reviewed to identify potential risks related to data loss, attack, or any other unauthorized alteration and/or access. | Data owners ensure that data is identified and inventoried and any changes to the data landscape are automatically detected and included within the catalog. The data landscape must then be reviewed to identify potential risks related to data loss, attack, or any other unauthorized alteration and/or access. | Data assets are known and can therefore be collected, tagged, and protected according to risk levels in alignment with a prioritization framework, and encrypted for protection. |

| Descriptions        | Outcomes           | ZT Impact |

| Data owners will capture active metadata that includes information about the access, sharing,transformation, and use of their data assets. Data outside of DLP and DRM scope such as File Shares and Databases is actively monitored for anomalous and malicious activity using alternative tooling. | Data owners will capture active metadata that includes information about the access, sharing, transformation, and use of their data assets. | Data in all states are detectable and observable. |

| Descriptions        | Outcomes           | ZT Impact |

| DoD organizations establish and implement a strategy for encrypting data at rest and in transit using Data Rights Management (DRM) tooling. The DRM solution utilizes data tags to determine protection and lastly integrates with ML and AI to automate protection. | DoD organizations establish and implement a strategy for encrypting data at rest and in transit. | Encrypting data in all states reduces the risk of unauthorized data access and improves data security. |

## Control Requirements 4.6
| Descriptions        | Outcomes           | ZT Impact | 
|-|:-:|:-:|:-:|:-:|
| DoD organizations utilize the identified enforcement points to deploy approved DLP tools and integrate tagged data attributes with DLP. Initially the DLP solution is put into a "monitor-only" mode to limit business impact and later using analytics is put into a "prevent" mode. Extended data tag attributes are used to feed the DLP solution and lastly integrate with ML and AI. | DoD organizations have identified enforcement points, deployed approved DLP tools at those enforcement points, and integrate tagged data attributes with DLP. | Data breaches and data exfiltration transmissions are detected and mitigated. |

Lastly the SDS solution(s) is integrated with DRM tooling improving protections. | DoD organizations ensure appropriate access to and use of data based on the data and user/NPE/device properties. | Unauthorized entities, or any entity on an unauthorized device cannot access data; Zero Trust cybersecurity will be sufficiently strong to separate community of interest data access for data in the same classification. |
